Local History
Lerner Auditorium of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center, 208 West 13th Street; (212) 614-9107.
The Historic Districts Council, an advocacy group for historic preservation, will sponsor two lectures.
The first, about the history of public baths, will be offered Wednesday at 6 p.m. by Joyce Mendelsohn, a historian and professor at the New School.
Richard A. Greenwald, a historian at the Merchant Marine Academy, will speak about the garment industry in New York on Feb. 11.
Reservations are required for both programs, which are free.
A Square Yard of Threads
New England Quilt Museum, 18 Shattuck Street (Market Street), Lowell, Mass.; (978) 452-4207.

''Time Squared: Art Quilts by the Manhattan Quilters Guild'' opens today and continues through March 20. The exhibition is of textiles by 16 members of the guild, a group of international fiber artists that meets occasionally in New York.

Each quilt in the themed show measures 36 by 36 inches. Among them is a depiction of the actor Harold Lloyd hanging from a giant clock in the 1923 silent film ''Safety Last.'' Quilt designs also include Times Square in New York and the rhythm of the seasons. One quilt incorporates historic photographs.
Each artist is also represented by a second work.
Open Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission is $5; students and those above 62, $4.
Classical Terra Cotta
Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street; (212) 535-7710.

''Playing With Fire: European Terra-Cotta Models, 1740-1840,'' an exhibition of 135 figures made during the Neoclassical era, begins on Wednesday and runs through April 25. On view will be figures representing self-portraits by artists, monuments to famous men and mythological characters.
Open Tuesday through Thursday, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 9:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. Admission is $12; students and the elderly, $7.
Figures in Clay
Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street (Bleecker Street); (212) 242-4106.

An exhibition of works by eight faculty members continues through Feb. 7. On view are a sculpture by Anna Siok incorporating dozens of small figurines like laborers and pedestrians, set among castles and architectural fragments, and masklike forms by Gisella Berger.
Open Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 6 p.m. Free admission.
Architecture in Japan
Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street; (212) 752-3015.
A three-day symposium on contemporary architecture in Japan will start on Feb. 26 at 6:30 p.m. with a keynote address by the architect Fumihiko Maki, who will speak about image and technology.

Mr. Maki's buildings include the Spiral Building in Tokyo (1985), the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco (1993) and the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which is under construction.

The symposium will continue on Feb. 27, from 2 to 5:30 p.m., and Feb. 28 from 9:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. Participants will examine such topics as the influence of traditional Japanese architecture on contemporary projects, the perception of space and the built environment in Japan, and the use of new materials and designs.

Among the participating architects will be Kengo Kuma, Jun Aoki and Shigeru Ban. Also expected to attend are Paola Antonelli, a curator of architecture and design for the Museum of Modern Art; Naomi Pollock, a Tokyo-based writer for the Architectural Record; and Hiroyuki Suzuki, a professor of architectural history and chairman of the University of Tokyo Graduate School of Architecture.

Reservations are required for the symposium. As of Feb. 1, admission for all three days is $120; members of the Japan Society or the Architectural League of New York, $100; students, $60. Tickets for Feb. 26 only are $25; members, $20; students, $12; for Feb. 27 only, $55; members, $45; students, $20; or for Feb. 28 only, $75; members, $45; students, $35. Discounts apply for tickets bought by Jan. 31.
